ResponsesInList.Title: Auto-linking overloading the database?
ResponsesInList.Text:
When my classes (at least 40 students) all try to access my moodle site they often see this error message: Error: Database connection failed. It is possible that the database is overloaded or otherwise not running properly. The site administrator should also check that the database details have been correctly specified in config.php I have made a post about this message in the General problems forum: click here to see the message . I
believe the the problem is that there are too many simultaneous
connections to the database . The hosting company told me that there is
a limit of 10 simultaneous connections, that this was plenty, and that
it could not be increased. It has just occurred to me that the
cause of this problem may be that the auto-linking function of the
glossary is causing too many connections to the database. Is this
possible? In both my online courses there are student created
glossaries. The idea is that as English language students they add
'difficult' words and phrases they come across in the online course
material. This has been very successful; after a month of classes there
are already 700 or so entries in each glossary. All these entries are
automatically linked. I have installed the 'Glossary Only First'
filter, but this doesn't stop the error message appearing.

ResponsesInList.Title: automatic linking required twice: why?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello. 1- When creating or updating a glossary, one has the option to tick the box: Automatically link glossary entries : 2- Then, when adding a new entry to that glossary, one again has the option; This entry should be automatically linked 1. Since the main way for students to access a glossary will be through the automatically linked words in resources & activities , I don't quite see the point of not automatically linking glossary entries. However there may exist cases where the glossary will be used "on its own", as it were, in which case that option will prove useful. 2. On the other hand, once a glossary has been created with the " Automatically link glossary entries " option set to Yes , I fail to see the logic behind having to click again - for each and every new entry- the This entry should be automatically linked option! The way things stand look so illogical to me that I often forget to tick that box and am puzzled when words are not autolinked in the resources... 3- Again I do accept that there might be, within an "automatically linked" type of glossary, a few instances of entries which should NOT be autolinked (why? I wonder), but it would be more logical if - in that type of glossary - entries were by default linked (still retaining the possibility to have some not linked).

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: automatic linking required twice: why?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Joseph, if I'm no wrong, when you enable "Automatically link glossary entries" at glossary level, you are ALLOWING users to select/deselect the "automatically linked" checkbox for each entry. And such option (and the rest of them related to linking) aren't showed if you disable such option at glossary level. About default values for options used by new glossary entries, you can configure them in Admin/Configuration/Modules/Glossary. With this, you will be able to have every new entry with options pre-filled as you want. Ciao

ResponsesInList.Title: Enhancement Request: Bookmark Manager
ResponsesInList.Text: There is one feature I've desired out of Moodle that the Glossary module is remarkably close to: a bookmark manager The motiviation is to have students discover resources on the Web which are relevant to the current learning activity. As these resources are found, they can be added and annotated to a bookmark manager. Just as comments can be added to glossary entries, so can they be added to bookmarks. Rather than starting from scratch each term, the bookmark manager data could be reused and expanded--becoming quite a useful student resource over time. As a testament to this idea, several years ago I programmed such a beast in perl and I still use the tool today http://www.opencentric.com/wrcc/xml/linker/link.cgi . At a technical level, the only major difference between this bookmark manager and the glossary is the addition of a single field (the name of the link) and some changes in terminology. Combining the two into a single module might take some doing, but starting with the Glossary module code and modifying it to create a Bookmark Manager module would probably be pretty straightforward. I would bite the bullet and crank it out myself but as a doctoral student I'm currently starved for time. So, I offer this post as a hope that there is someone else out there who finds the idea valuable and has the time to whup up a new module. Thanks, -TAG

ResponsesInList.Title: Moodle Newbie
ResponsesInList.Text: Can anyone point me to the information about installing Glossary. I downloaded it, put it in the /mod folder, clicked on view.php and found the following message: Must specify glossary ID or course module ID. Where do I do this at? In the other php files it tell me: A required parameter was missing. I'm assuming that is the glossary ID or course module ID. Thanks for any help!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle Newbie
ResponsesInList.Text: The glossary is not an optional module - it comes bundled with the standard Moodle distribution, so you don't have to install it separately. To add it to your course, turn editing on and then select "Glossary" from the "Add an activity" list. The glossary (just like any activity) must be a part of a course. If you access the view.php page directly, you will get the error about missing IDs. Hope this helps, Przemek

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle Newbie
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks Przemyslaw. I just didn't know where to look. Should I remove the folder "glossary" that I downloaded and placed in the /mod folder?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle Newbie
ResponsesInList.Text: The folder "glossary" should be there. However, since you downloaded and installed the glossary separately, you overwrote the version which was included in the main distribution with the version which you downloaded later. This might (but might just as well not) cause some problems. To be on the safe side, I recommend you delete the "glossary" folder and upload it again, but not the code you found in the glossary.zip file (the optional download ). Instead, extract the mod/glossary folder from the zip file which included the whole distribution of Moodle and use this.

ResponsesInList.Text:
Look at what "Display format" you're using. I'm using the "Simple Dictionary" and it is working just fine to list in alpa order....Sounds as if you may be using a Continous format? Display format This setting specifies the way that each entry will be shown within the glossary. The default formats are: Simple Dictionary : looks like a conventional dictionary with separate entries. No authors are displayed and attachments are shown as links. Continuous : shows the entries one after other without any kind of separation but the editing icons. Full with Author : A forum-like display format showing author's data. Attachments are shown as links. Full without Author : A forum-like display format that does not show author's data. Attachments are shown as links. Encyclopedia : Like 'Full with Author' but attached images are shown inline. FAQ : Useful for displaying lists of Frequently Asked Questions. It automatically appends the words QUESTION and ANSWER in the concept and definition respectively. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Link but then switch off?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Tim, "manual calls to the glossary" mean linking to each of the entries by hand!! And I think that you cannot add code for manually calling the glossary. Autolinking works in something that we could call "Moodle-Output-Chain" where EVERY Moodle content is passed to one CENTRAL function. This function executes (in a chain) al the transformations (convert to html, add smilies, process filters...) as needed, depending of your configuration. So, adding/modifying code in theme header and or enclosing everything inside "nolink" tags won't have effect, because filters are applied at "individual content" level, not at "page" level. Hope this clarify things a bit...ciao

A cache is a collection of duplicate data, where the original data is expensive to fetch or  compute (usually in terms of access time) relative to the cache. Future accesses to the data can be made by accessing the cached copy rather than refetching or recomputing the original data, so that the perceived average access time is lower. Caches may mark the cached data as 'stale' when the original data is changed, but this is not always the case. The reason caches work at all is that many access patterns in typical computer applications have locality of reference. There are several sorts of locality, but we mainly mean that often the same data is accessed frequently or with accesses that are close together in time, or that data near to each other are accessed close together in time. [Source: Wikipedia http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cache#CPU_memory_cache 27June2004] Note - the above link has more detailed information about CPU cache memory. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Glossary is nearly ready for 1.3 - please test it
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Steven, glossary auto-linking speed is affected by some different variables: - Number of items in your glossaries. - Speed of your server. - Caching time. The time necessary to auto-link your tests is directly proportional to the number of items in your glossaries. Perhaps you should reduce the number of items to be linked (deactivating their "auto-link" variable). Obviously, the speed of your server is a crucial variable. Differences can be notable!! And finally, increasing caching time for filters can help to improve things, but the 1st time or when the cache is expired you will notice the slow-down. As Moodle is evolving every day, I'm sure we'll see some improvements in this area soon (I'm thinking about some possibilities just now). Ciao

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Dictionary glossary with 100,000 words possible?
ResponsesInList.Text: A glossary of 100K entries can't be handled ATM... Unless they are not automatically linked... I can't see a way with the current database design... Well... It CAN be handled.. but the answer time to show every post, resource, etc, would be simple nonesense. and a parsing system which allows users to enter the URL of a site so that all the words in that site are auto linked to the glossary/dictionary This is a feature that was recently added to the glossary... ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Dictionary glossary with 100,000 words possible?
ResponsesInList.Text: I don't think so... The autolinking feature is, in fact, a feature of Moodle's core, not glossary's so the glossary module has (almost) nothing to do with the process itself. If it is made to the glossary, it will has to be made to everything else, and it will affect other filters... I don't think this is the right path to go. It should be a redesign of the db, the process or, more probably, both (and it if it is ever done, it will be after 1.2 is released anyway). By the way.. upgrading won't be difficult... will be extremely easy in fact... The hard work will be in re-coding your changes... Perhaps you won't need them anymore, though. Will
